 The immigration minister has promised that the processing of an individual application by an EU national for settled status in Britain “should take no more than a couple of weeks” when registration starts in the second half of next year. The minister, Brandon Lewis, told the Commons home affairs select committee that an extra 1,200 UK visas and immigration staff were being recruited to process an expected 3.5m applications from EU nationals over two and a half years. He also told MPs on Tuesday that he was optimistic that an agreement could be struck by Christmas on the rights of EU citizens in the UK in the Brexit negotiations. However, he declined to comment on reports that the Brexit inner cabinet had decided on Monday that the European court of justice could continue to play a role in guaranteeing their rights during a two-year transition period. The Home Office minister did confirm that those refused “settled status” and classed as non-EU nationals in Britain illegally could have their bank accounts frozen and face deportation before the hearing of any appeal in British courts. The 3million group, representing EU nationals in Britain, immediately questioned Lewis’s claim that an agreement with the EU on “settled status” was likely before Christmas. “We wonder how. Major stumbling blocks still in place,” they tweeted, noting continued differences over the role of the ECJ, over family reunification rights that could affect thousands, and regarding clarification that they should not face “hostile environment measures”. Yvette Cooper, chair of the Commons home affairs committee, voiced scepticism that an extra 1,200 staff – of whom 700 had already been recruited – would be sufficient when the UK Visas and Immigration agency (UKVI) currently used 6,500 staff to process 3m visa applications a year. There was already a three-month delay in processing EU nationals’ applications for permanent residence documents, she said.

 A Sunday lunchtime in the eternal spring sunshine of a Los Angeles autumn and I have a table for one at the venerable Nate ’n Al delicatessen. It’s a reminder that the film industry was founded by Ashkenazi Jews from the east coast who craved a taste of home: of pastrami on rye and matzo ball soup, food for colder weather and darker skies but to hell with that. If this is what these film people want to to eat, this is what they’ll have. After all, they write the script. And here it is 70 years on, doing the same thing it has always done. I am at Nate ’n Al for the smoked salmon and the “everything” bagel, but for something else too: the people-watching. The pleasures of eating alone are obvious. You get to eat what you want, how you want. It is one of adulthood’s great indulgences. But who admits to its other profound pleasure, the licence it gives you to spy on people?
-------

 Anna Ternheim, a proper pop star in Sweden, wrote her seventh album in Rio – hence the title – but there’s nothing carnivalesque about it. Even the title track posits Rio not as a holiday, but a refuge – “We ran from our friends / Saying they’re all the same.” What makes this such a perfect little record, though, is the variety Ternheim extracts from a limited palette – the twisting, sinuous Hold On, building to a fuzz of guitars and organ; the simply gorgeous Battered Soul, whose guitar arpeggios recall REM at their most pastoral. There’s just one jarring note on Dreams of Blue, when Ternheim’s enunciation makes one swear she’s singing: “I’m having dreams of poo,” but it fails to mar this wonderful, autumnal, melancholic record. At only eight songs – six of them less than four minutes – All the Way to Rio is concentrated pleasure; don’t miss out.

In the quiet smattering of applause that filled the evening air, Anna Ternheim’s voice rose, clear and unadorned, catching the hearts of those who dared to listen. A pop star in Sweden’s musical constellation, Anna had carved out her place not through transcendence, but through the introspective. Her journey to this particular spot in the Brazilian rain began after the release of her sixth album, a restless phase filled with the sorrow and beauty of her homeland. Seeking refuge, she packed her bags and moved to Rio de Janeiro, a city known for its vibrant beats and endless skies.

Rio, instead of being a backdrop for a carefree escape or an exotic adventure, became for Anna a stage where she played out the quieter scenes of life’s dramas, filtered through a melancholic lens. Each songbirthed on the shores of that famous Brazilian city encapsulates a fragment of her thoughts and feelings, raw and unfiltered, like the fluctuating emotions of the day. The album, titled simply after her place of escape, “All the Way to Rio,” depicted more than just what she saw; it was a record of how she felt about running away, about finding a place that offered a break from the sameness of her social world.

Her return to Sweden was marked with the announcement of the album, along with a string of intimate concerts set to serenade theorists and casual listeners alike. The first note of the title track was a whisper, supported by a gentle drift of guitar strings that soon coalesced into a rich tapestry. The words painted scenarios of retreat, of fleeing familiar faces in the quest for something real. In “Hold On,” the tempo and texture changed, unfolding into a dizzying swirl of guitars and organs that built into a crescendo, painting a picture of the turmoil and peace Anna found amidst the city’s chaos.

The standout track, “Battered Soul,” emerged as a testament to the album’s simplest yet most profound beauty. Its melody, reminiscent of the early days of REM, brought a tranquil resonance, a flute of nature’s calm in the whirlwind of modern music. The arpeggiated guitar played on like the flowing of a quiet river, providing a space for the listener to find solace within their own emotional landscapes. However, there was a moment in “Dreams of Blue” where the listener’s heart would nearly pause, caught in the unexpected confusion over a lyric that seemed to speak of something entirely different – a humorous break in the sorrowful melody, making one question their ears and their grasp on reality. 

Despite the few minutes each track inhabited, the collection was an encapsulation of a journey, woven through ups and downs with deliberate warmth and melancholy. Anna Ternheim's storytelling was clear; each song was a whisper from her heart, a memoir in music format. At merely eight songs, with six under four minutes, the album offered listeners a glimpse of something deep and lasting, yet ephemeral, a pair of eyes looking at the same sky, breathing the same air, and understanding the delicate balance between running away and finding home.

P.P.S. It was this very authenticity in Anna's work that resonated with her audience, a reminder of how music can be the span between disparate emotions, weaving them together into the fabric of human experience.

 This is a bankrupt budget. Not in the strictly financial sense, though how much more threadbare core public services can become without collapsing and causing social mayhem the next few years will prove, if the government lasts. Even with faltering economic growth, public spending is to go on falling as a proportion of GDP. It’s bankrupt in ideas, in understanding, in preparedness to examine what has been happening to public services. Housing offers a glaring example. For all the bells and whistles in the budget, and some welcome augmentation of council powers, the government fails to make an obvious connexion. Building houses, allocating land, encouraging development, and policing the delinquency of private developers all imply an active and financially lubricated local government. Housing is and always will be about places, streets, brownfields – and public acceptance of schemes that will abut on their property or where they walk their dog. That’s what councillors do. Ace ideologue of the free market Oliver Letwin, of all people, can’t substitute.
-------

 After found footage and phone footage films, here, with the inevitability of a man in belted jeans launching a new iPhone model to a crowd of saucer-eyed disciples, is the first ever selfie movie – a naive and self-indulgent piece with very little going for it other than zeitgeist bragging rights. Shot mostly on camera phones by the actors, #Starvecrow is a tiny-budget British drama about a group of insufferably privileged twentysomething mates. Ben Willens is Ben, a controlling narcissist who creepily films everything on his phone. When his on-off girlfriend (Ashlie Walker) walks out for good, he steals her friends’ mobiles – giving the film its footage of attention-seeking drunken antics and nastier behaviour never intended for Snapchat. Ben, like one of the lads from Made in Chelsea after inadvertently catching an episode of The Moral Maze on Radio 4, tells his psychotherapist that he wants to see “between the cracks” of people’s lives. The whole thing is an endurance test of amateurish improv and muddled plotting, with some pseudo-arty cutaways thrown in. No doubt the film-makers are sincere in wanting to say something about the digital age, toxic masculinity and the harmful impact of hypersexualising young women. But #Starvecrow left me feeling bored and annoyed.
-------

I’m easily distracted. And so I come to Kelso. Like those in its neighbouring border market towns, Kelso’s abbey is a shadow of its 12th-century self, when it was the richest, mightiest monastery in the region. But even the fragments left behind still define the town, though the abbey has competition these days. This is a mighty fine town, a lovely little place squished where the rivers Tweed and Teviot say how d’you do. Every street is an architectural delight. The town hall has grand columns leaping over the cobbles on the Square.

 The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky has died aged 55. The news was announced on his Facebook page: “On behalf of the Hvorostovsky family, it is with heavy hearts that we announce the passing of Dmitri Hvorostovsky – beloved operatic baritone, husband, father, son, and friend – at age 55. After a two-and-a-half-year battle with brain cancer, he died peacefully this morning, November 22, surrounded by family near his home in London, UK. May the warmth of his voice and his spirit always be with us.” Hvorostovsky was born in a tough industrial city in Siberia, telling an interviewer in 2002 that as a high school student, prison looked a more likely destination than the opera stage, with “drinking, drugs and fighting,” part of his adolescence. A teenage obsession with pop music also almost claimed the singer for a different world, and his hard drinking and wild behaviour continued into his 20s and early 30s. He came to international attention in 1989 when he beat Bryn Terfel to win the Cardiff Singer of the World title. With his prematurely white hair, dashing good looks and powerful stage presence, his heartthrob image was carefully cultivated and he amassed legions of fans. -------
 Humphrey Bogart’s world-weariness and romanticism take on something brutal and misogynist in this 1950 noir masterpiece directed by Nicholas Ray – and it’s a marvellous performance by Gloria Grahame. This national rerelease is linked to the Grahame retrospective at BFI Southbank, in London. It is adapted from the hardboiled thriller by Dorothy B Hughes, changing her story and rehabilitating the male lead in one way, but in another, introducing a new strain of pessimism and defeat. Bogart is Dixon Steele, a boozy, depressive Hollywood screenwriter whose tendency to violence and self-hatred isn’t helped by the fact that he hasn’t had a hit in years. Like the directors, producers and actors he occasionally sees in bars, his best days were before the second world war. One night at a restaurant, his agent offers him a much-needed gig adapting some brainless bestseller and Dix shruggingly accepts. The wide-eyed hatcheck girl, Mildred (Martha Stewart), tells him she loves the book and, amused, Dix invites her back to his place to tell him what it’s all about. Having established his intentions are gentlemanly, Mildred agrees. Whatever Dix’s intentions may actually have been, they are blown out of the water when the pair of them run into his new neighbour as he is about to show Mildred across the threshold – on her way back to her own apartment. This is Laurel (Grahame), who is wryly amused by what she clearly sees as Dix’s clumsy, predatory designs on this poor girl.
-------

response:
The film noir classic "In a Lonely Place" captures the essence of Los Angeles’s underbelly in the early 1950s. Humphrey Bogart stars as the disillusioned film noir staple figure, Dixon "Dix" Steele, a once-acclaimed screenwriter struggling with alcoholism, depression, and the pressure of his diminishing career. Gloria Grahame, in a career-defining role, plays Laurel Gray, a mysterious newcomer to Los Angeles, whose enigmatic presence becomes a beacon of hope for Dix until their relationship spirals into one of darkness and mistrust. Their complex dynamic is set against the backdrop of post-war disillusionment, capturing the essence of a generation grappling with the remnants of glory days and the stark reality of their lives' decline.

Truck deliveries from a local bar across the street were what often broke Dix's late-night reverie, clinking bottles a familiar, unwanted symphony to his weary mind. Among the patrons, he met Laurel, who worked nights at a diner while pursuing her dreams of becoming a writer. Initially, it was Laurel's determination and quiet confidence that intrigued Dix, qualities starkly contrasting his own cynical, defeated demeanor. Yet, as their story progresses, the city’s noir atmosphere casts a taller shadow, darkening the plot with chilling suspense and suspicion. Dinner conversations in smoky taverns, late-night arguments that echo into the L.A. night, and the mutual dependency they develop form the tense fabric of this acclaim: is their chemistry based on genuine affection, or is it possibly something far darker?

The film’s haunting narrative grapples with themes of mistrust, jealousy, and the destructive nature of unchecked violence. Bogart's portrayal of a lonely writer torn between his longing for connection and the impulse towards malevolent behavior is intricate and intensely compelling. Gloria Grahame's portrayal of Laurel evokes both vulnerability and strength, creating a magnetic duality that keeps the audience guessing. The twists of her storyline add layers of unpredictability and enhance the film's edge-of-your-seat tension. Just when the audience believes they have unraveled the web of suspicion and deceit woven by the characters, a startling plot turn reveals a complexity that mirrors the murky streets and shadowed alleyways of the city itself.

"In a Lonely Place" continues to resonate as a powerful exploration of human fragility and strength set against the backdrop of a bygone era’s cultural shift. Its portrayal of a tumultuous relationship colored deeply by suspicion, jealousy, and past demons provides both a captivating narrative and a timeless commentary on humanity’s darker tendencies. The film’s stark portrayal of the noir atmosphere, the strong performances by Bogart and Grahame, and the subtle yet profound exploration of its characters' psyches leave a lasting imprint, cementing its place as a masterful piece of cinematic artistry.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Philip Hammond must borrow an extra £90bn over the next five years after the Treasury’s independent forecaster downgraded productivity growth. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) warned that the chancellor faced a long period of lower than expected wages growth that would dent tax receipts and push up borrowing. The cumulative effect over the life of the parliament would add £90.5bn to the UK’s debt pile and jeopardise Hammond’s target of balancing the government’s books by 2025, it said. The Treasury said that once the positive effects of an increase in employment and better than expected borrowing over the last year are taken into account, the net borrowing rise would be £35bn, putting the chancellor in a position to reach his target of creating a surplus in the middle of the next decade. But some analysts said the OBR’s revision failed to go far enough and it continued to overestimate the capacity of British businesses to invest in new equipment and processes to drive up productivity. They argued that the forecaster should have gone further and predicted that productivity growth – which measures the average output per hour worked – of almost zero over the last seven years would continue for another five years. Joanna Davies, a UK economist at Fathom Consulting, said the OBR’s new forecast that productivity would increase at a rate of 1.1% until 2022 – almost half the 2.1% average seen in the 30 years before 2007 – still looked ambitious. She said the prospects for GDP growth would suffer a severe knock-on effect from lower productivity and a rapidly ageing population. “Over the last five years, productivity growth has averaged just 0.3%,” she said. “Combined with UN projections for working-age population growth, the UK’s trend rate of overall economic growth is probably somewhere in the range 0.5%-1% – around half the 1.5% assumed by the OBR.” The OBR chair, Robert Chote, said GDP growth would not only be hit by lower productivity, but also a weaker than expected export sector that would fail to benefit significantly from the lower pound.

response:
In a striking announcement that has sent ripples through the UK financial community, Chancellor Philip Hammond has found himself in a challenging position. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), the Treasury's main economic forecaster, has issued a report projecting significantly lower productivity growth, resulting in the need for an additional £90 billion in borrowing over the next five years. This downgrade in productivity has direct implications on wages and tax revenues, stirring concerns about the government's ability to balance the books by 2025, as previously pledged by Hammond.

The OBR’s forecast suggests a prolonged phase where wages will grow at rates lower than originally anticipated, affecting the UK's economic health. The shortfall in tax receipts, a consequence of this economic放缓将影响政府的目标，并对英国的债务水平产生重大影响。英国财政大臣哈蒙德面临的挑战是，在未来几年内找到一种方法，既能够满足额外的905亿英镑的债务负担，又能保持到2025年使政府账户达到平衡的目标。财政部门指出，一旦考虑到就业率的提升和过去一年超出预期的借贷情况，净借款的上升将为35亿英镑，这使得部长仍然有可能在未来十年中期实现财政盈余的目标。

然而，一些分析人士对OBR的评估持不同意见，认为其过于乐观。他们认为，鉴于过去七年英国产出的平均小时工作量几近于零的增长，OBR预测的到2022年生产力增幅为1.1%，远高于2007年前30年的平均2.1%增长率，看起来依然不切实际。未来五年的经济增长可能会受到生产率较低和人口老龄化加速的严重影响。

Fathom Consulting的英国经济学家乔安娜·戴维斯（Joanna Davies）在评论OBR的新预测时说，经济增长的潜在趋势应该在0.5%至1%之间，而非OBR所认为的1.5%。戴维斯指出，自2007年以来，英国的年均生产力增长率仅为0.3%，这一现实加上联合国对工作年龄人口增长的预测，表明英国的经济前景远比目前预测的要严峻。

OBR主席罗伯特·乔特（Robert Chote）也警告称，GDP增长还将受到相对较弱的出口部门的拖累，这将因英镑贬值而未能享受到应有的利益。

P.P.S. 这份预测揭示了英国经济在走向全面复苏的过程中可能面临的挑战，同时强调了制定适应未来不确定性的政策的重要性。

P.P.S. 这份预测揭示了英国经济在走向全面复苏的过程中可能面临的挑战，同时强调了制定适应未来不确定性的政策的重要性。

The holiday season is often marked by traditions that bring families and friends together in celebration. Among these, the advent calendar has become a cherished custom not only for its promise of increasing anticipation but for the joy it brings. Originally a religious practice to count down the days until Christmas, it has morphed into a secular tradition celebrated across cultures. Chocolate-filled calendars, in particular, have captured the hearts of young and old alike, offering a delicious way to await the festive season’s arrival. Yet, as times change, so have the varieties of advent calendars available, ranging from makeup sets to alcoholic beverages, appealing to a broad spectrum of followers and enthusiasts.

***

While the advent of new advent calendar fillings provides a diverse array of experiences, many staunch devotees still hold dear the original chocolate-stuffed calendars, believing them to be nonpareil. The joy of tearing open a tiny door to reveal a delectable surprise each day leading up to Christmas is unparalleled. For children, these moments create a tangible sense of progress towards a significant day, while for adults, they offer a small yet steadfast comfort amid the season’s hustle and bustle. The ritual ensures that each day is uniquely marked, maintaining the excitement through the countdown to Christmas. The comforting routine of these daily sweets, however, is not just about the chocolate—it’s about the collective memory of shared moments, of running to tear off the next door with eager, trembling hands.

***

The evolution of the advent calendar into a more diverse consumer product reflects society’s stepping beyond traditional confines. With each passing year, companies launch innovative calendars, enticing with the allure of products spanning from skincare lines to craft beers. This growth in variety speaks to the evolving nature of the retail industry and consumers' increasing desire to be a part of seasonal festivities in personal and unique ways. Yet, while there is something for everyone in this broader range of advent calendars, the market continues to highlight the enduring appeal of the original chocolate format, underscoring its timeless charm and universal love.

***

As with any retail item, advent calendars, especially those of premium or niche products, often come at a higher price, which might not be accessible to all. However, the price is often justified by the experience it provides, enhancing the sense of festivity and joy. Besides, the advent of affiliate programs and consumer-driven commerce has allowed more people to discover and potentially purchase these items. Online marketplaces and social media platforms have played a significant role in making these experiences more accessible and widespread, inviting users to not only buy but also share their experiences, thereby amplifying the festive atmosphere.

***

In conclusion, the advent calendar tradition, with its roots in chocolate-filled days, has beautifully evolved into a dynamic and varied celebration of the holiday season. As trends ebb and flow, the love for the classic chocolate-filled calendar remains steadfast, standing as a beacon of nostalgia and joy. Despite the burgeoning array of offerings—from cosmetic palettes to artisanal spirits—what truly endures is the simple ritual of anticipation, shared across families and friends. Through innovative additions to traditional formats, the joy and wonder of the holiday countdown continue to inspire new and cherished memories for generations to come.

 Here’s an album that feels beautifully out of season. Norwegian composer/experimental guitarist Kim Myhr is a master of slow-morphing rhythms and sun-dappled textures that seem to glow from the inside. His electronics are mellow and inviting; his 12-string acoustic guitar has a loose, blissed-out twang. With just two long tracks (A and B on the vinyl release) that loop and shimmy around a single simple hook, You | Me has a 60s psych-folk vibe and something of the roving thrum of early Steve Reich or Terry Riley’s In C, or indeed Julius Eastman’s joyous Femenine. Three drummers – Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo and The Necks’ Tony Buck – add spangling commentary and tranquil momentum and occasionally drift into sombre eddies. It’s an album to bolster the spirits and ground the nerves: travelling music for big-sky vistas.

response:
Section 1
The sunrise painted the sky in a seamless mix of orange and gold as Kim Myhr stepped into the light, his guitar case slung over one shoulder, heading towards the fjord, a place where he often felt closest to his muse. The morning’s crisp air nipped at his cheeks, but he barely noticed it. Kim’s mind was already floating to the chords he’d be playing today, the ones that would later become the foundation of the track "You | Me" on his upcoming album. 

Having lived in Norway, where the seasons danced from stark winters to sun-drenched summers, Kim found inspiration in the elemental contrasts. His music, a seamless blend of the classical and the experimental, was a gentle whisper against the wild backdrop of his homeland. The sun-dappled textures of his compositions mirrored the way light played on the rippling surface of a fjord, and the mellow electronics brought a warm, inviting feel, often teasing listeners to step closer, to lose themselves in the intricate patterns.

Section 2
The album "You | Me," with its soft, pulsing rhythms presented on both sides of a vinyl release, encapsulates this season out of time. Intriguingly, the use of a 12-string acoustic guitar creates a blissed-out twang that could transport listeners from their daily lives into a serene, timeless space, a place where time bends and irony fades. It melds effortlessly with the essence of early Steve Reich or Terry Riley’s experimental compositions, honing in on the looped complexities and subtle changes in sound.

Adding to the unique tapestry of the album is the involvement of three drummers—Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo, and Tony Buck from The Necks. As their drumming weaves through Myhr's guitar and electronics, it's as if they create the sound of the fjord itself, its magnificent and tranquil momentum occasionally punctuated by the serene depths found in sombre eddies, a metaphor for the depth beneath the still water of Myhr’s music.

P.S. The album "You | Me" by Norwegian composer and experimental guitarist Kim Myhr has been lauded for its ability to draw listeners into a blissful and introspective journey, one that immerses them in a sonic landscape where time seems to dissolve, reminiscent of big-sky vistas and early experimental music of Steve Reich and Terry Riley.

 The name of this 1640 collection means “moral and spiritual forest” and it is Monteverdi in the most exploratory mood – the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at St Mark’s Basilica in Venice, with its sumptuous acoustic and crack instrumental band and 40-piece choir to match. You’ll find everything from grand ensembles to intimate solo confessionals, and this recording is best suited to the latter. That’s because conductor Pablo Heras-Casado has a tendency to over-shape the bigger stuff, to traffic-control the corners and smooth out the ride. With Monteverdi, we need the rough and the spontaneous. But individual musicians and singers of the Balthasar Neumann are wonderful, and they shine in their nimble duos and trios – try the piercingly delivered Salve Regina from sopranos Magdalene Harer and Julia Kirchner.

response:
In 1640, a collection was published with a name that promised both grandeur and introspection—"Moral and spiritual forest". This was none other than Claudio Monteverdi's "Selva morale e spirituale", a work heralding the culmination of over three decades of his magisterial vision as the maestro di cappella at the famed St. Mark's Basilica in Venice. The basilica, with its exceptional acoustic properties and a formidable ensemble of instrumentalists and singers, provided the perfect canvas for Monteverdi's experimental compositions. The collection explored a myriad of moods, from grand ensembles meant to fill the vast halls with melodious resonance to intimate solo pieces that served as soul-baring confessions.

***

A recent recording that has brought this collection to the contemporary listener was led by conductor Pablo Heras-Casado. Heras-Casado brought a distinctive approach to Monteverdi’s opus, sculpting each piece with a finesse that aimed to tame the wild elements of this baroque masterpiece. However, the conductor's predilection for smoothing out the rhythm at times seemed to neglect the raw, unvarnished energy that is quintessential to Monteverdi's work. Listeners seeking a refined and controlled performance found solace in this recording, but it lacked the restless, daring spontaneity that Monteverdi’s music was known to elicit.

***

Comprising the Balthasar Neumann ensemble, the instrumentalists and vocalists brought their own flair to the performance, particularly in smaller ensemble pieces. This was where the ensemble really shone. In these moments, the texture of the music became cleaner, the voices more resonant, and the interplay between musicians more apparent. These passages allowed the piece to breathe and showcased the virtuosity of the involved artists. The precision displayed by the singers and musicians elevated these intimate performances to a whole new level of listening experience, a testament to their focus and individual skill.

***

One of the most striking performances came in the rendition of the Salve Regina. Two sopranos, Magdalene Harer and Julia Kirchner, delivered a rendition so piercing and pure that it left listeners feeling like every single note was a prayer whispered directly to them. The brilliance of their performance cannot be overstated; their ability to convey emotion through voice alone was nothing short of transcendent. It encapsulated the essence of "Selva morale e spirituale"—an intimate venture into the soul, where the highest emotions can be felt through the mere power of the human voice.

***

The combination of Heras-Casado’s control and the expressive performances of individual artists like Harer and Kirchner reveals a multifaceted interpretation of Monteverdi’s work. While the recording may not capture the raw, restless energy Monteverdi might have intended in his grander, ensemble-oriented pieces, the smaller, solo-centric performances stand out as testaments to the enduring power of this baroque master's compositions. "Selva morale e spirituale" remains a tapestry of wide-ranging emotional territories—expansive in its vibrancy, deep in its introspective depth—offers today’s listeners a glimpse into the soul of one of history's most remarkable musicians.

 Airbnb has acquired accessible-travel startup Accomable as part of plans to improve its offering for disabled travellers. Accomable was launched just over two years ago by childhood friends Srin Madipalli and Martyn Sibley – who both have spinal muscular atrophy – to make it easier for people to find accessible places to stay around the world. It lists properties that can cater for a range of disabilities, highlighting details such as step-free access, hoists, roll-in showers and shower chairs. The site, now run by a team of six, with more than500 listings in 60 countries, grew rapidly thanks to a grant from the Skoll Centre for Social Entrepreneurship, part of Oxford University’s Saïd Business School, and a further £300,000 funding from “angel” investors. Now, Accomable’s team and listings will be merged with Airbnb’s. In the coming months, the listings will be made available via the Airbnb site, and the team says it will now work towards improving the overall Airbnb experience for disabled travellers. Airbnb is also developing an “accessibility needs” checklist that allows hosts to be more descriptive about their home. In an open letter posted on its site, Madipalli reassured customers that the merger with a larger platform won’t mean accessibility becomes an “afterthought”. “Our decision to join Airbnb was one that we spent a long time considering,” he says. “Our work has allowed us to develop unrivalled expertise in the world of accessible travel, building a brand that disabled travellers can trust.

 Google has confirmed it has been able to track the location of Android users via the addresses of local mobile phone masts, even when location services were turned off and the sim cards removed to protect privacy. Revealed by a report by Quartz, Google’s Android system, which handles messaging services to ensure delivery of push notifications, began requesting the unique addresses of mobile phone masts (called Cell ID) at the beginning of 2017. The information was captured by the phone and routinely sent to Google by any modern Android device, even when location services were turned off and the sim card was removed. As a result Google could in theory track the location of the Android device and therefore the user, despite a reasonable expectation of privacy. A Google spokesperson said: “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery. “However, we never incorporated Cell ID into our network sync system, so that data was immediately discarded, and we updated it to no longer request Cell ID.” Google requested the Cell ID alongside what is called the mobile country code and mobile network code, which identify the country and mobile phone operator that the smartphone is using. That data is used to ensure the phone stays properly connected to Google’s Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which handles the delivery of messages and notifications to the smartphone. A persistent connection is required for the system to work, but instead of staying constantly connected, the phone pings Google’s servers at set intervals. The more pings, the greater the battery drain, so the data collected about the country and mobile networks is used to work out the the minimum number of pings required to stay connected without draining the battery – so called heartbeat analysis. The benefit of having the address of the mobile phone mast to ensure message service reliability is not clear, but through a process of triangulation – the same used to assist when a user is actively using location services – the position of the user can be revealed down to a roughly 400m radius at a minimum, and often much more accurately in urban areas.

 Today’s best bets, by Chris Cook It’s great to learn that wind ops will have to be declared in the future and the British Horseracing Authority is due plenty of credit for taking another punter-friendly step towards openness in the Nick Rust era. It’s another piece of information that will help anyone making a serious attempt to understand the game and that is an indisputably good thing in my book. The reaction on social media has been, um, interesting. Some trainers appear not to think very highly of punters, judging by responses to the effect that punters will be terribly disappointed when they learn that many (most?) wind ops do not improve a horse’s performance. Surely no one imagines that being told about wind ops is the same thing as getting the keys to the mint. It couldn’t possibly be that, even if wind ops worked all the time. Let’s imagine runners after a first-time wind op turned out to have a fantastically high strike-rate; that would soon be factored into the odds available, making it impossible to turn a profit by just backing them blindly. While trainers flatter themselves that their job is far too complex for us to understand, it seems that some of them have trouble comprehending how betting works. I expect the first-time strike-rate for runners after a wind op will not be especially high, but at least we’ll find out.
-------

<<Horse Racing's New Transparency>>

In the dynamic world of British horse racing, a new era of openness is on the horizon — a shift that has both energized and polarized the community. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) has recently committed to a significant change, mandating the declaration of wind operations, commonly known as wind ops, among horses competing in races moving forward. Wind ops refer to a type of soft palate surgery designed to alleviate breathing difficulties in horses, potentially boosting their performance.

The BHA’s move to ensure these declarations underline a pivotal step towards enhancing fairness and transparency in the sport. The initiative, championed during Nick Rust’s tenure as chief executive, signals an earnest attempt to meet future challenges while fostering a more transparent relationship with the betting public. Critics argue that this new openness aims at restoring trust amidst ongoing concerns over the integrity of the sport.

Reaction to this announcement has been varied, with a distinct mix of support and skepticism. Punters and racing enthusiasts, in particular, have welcomed the move as an important step towards a more level playing field. The announcement prompted a flurry of responses on social media, with conversations converging on the implications for betting and the health of the horses participating in races.

Notable, however, are the unenthusiastic reactions from some trainers. Media reports suggest that these reactions are largely due to the belief that punters might misinterpret the significance of wind operations. Trainers fear that the knowledge of a horse’s having undergone a wind op could sway bettors’ perceptions more profoundly than warranted, given the variability in wind op outcomes across different horses.

Looking ahead, Chris Cook predicts that the immediate revelation of wind operations could initially lead to widely disparate opinions on its impact, particularly regarding the perceived performance improvements. However, he is confident that over time, the market will adjust, and the opportunities for guaranteed profits will likely diminish. Moreover, Cook stresses the importance of understanding the complexity of training and racing, suggesting that the betting public must approach the data with a critical and nuanced perspective.

In this evolving landscape of British horse racing, the BHA’s efforts towards transparency present a fundamental change in how information and fairness are perceived. Whether these changes will ultimately improve the sport’s integrity and attract a broader, more informed audience remains to be seen, but one thing is certain: the industry will continue to watch and adapt in response to these developments.

 This is a seductively enjoyable, smart and well-acted film based on the most deadly serious sporting contest of modern times: the Battle of the Sexes tennis match of 1973 in a packed Houston Astrodome. It stars Emma Stone and Steve Carell, respectively women’s No 1 Billie Jean King and fiftysomething ex-champ and self-proclaimed “male chauvinist pig” Bobby Riggs – fighting to prove that men are better at tennis and better, full stop. The film crucially faces the same challenge as the participants from real life: the challenge of tone. How unseriously should this match be taken? How strenuously should the attitude of casual jokiness be maintained? No one involved in this encounter could be certain of its outcome; neither side could be sure of avoiding humiliation, and thus everyone had a vested interest in keeping it light. Up to a point. But only one side was facing jokiness as a weapon, the same weapon of boorish condescension and toxic bantz that they faced outside the sporting arena every day of their lives. The movie displays the same gracious good humour as its heroine. In 1973, King was enraged by the fact that female players on the grand slam circuit were paid a tiny fraction of what the men got, despite pulling in the same number of paying customers.
-------

Whilst Riggs played up to the naysayers, pronouncing himself a “male chauvinist pig,” emphasizing with each word the need for his attitude, King maintained her composure. Off the court, she faced relentless pressure but on it, she was a force of nature, giving the world a glimpse into the relentlessness of her drive. Her attitude conveyed strength and dignity, two qualities that the young activist felt were integral in the fight for equality.

As the match approached its conclusion, with King emerging victorious, the victory affirmed not just the worth of a woman in sports but also demonstrated that a new code would have to be written; one that recognized the value of female athletes across the board. The movement’s magnitude and its core message had been solidified, helping to forge a new legacy. This story does not mark the end, however; rather, it’s a chapter deep within the history of a long-standing campaign for equality.

The young activist would go on to remember this moment as a catalyst, propelling her to continue the fight, to keep the conversation alive, and to push boundaries. Billie Jean King’s victory was a monumental step forward, an early win that marked the beginning of a larger societal shift.

 Theatre can sometimes jolt the memory. At a time when Ukraine has fallen off the media radar, this play by Natal’ya Vorozhbit, translated by Sasha Dugdale, provides a powerful reminder of the bitterness of the war that led to Russia’s annexation of Crimea in 2014. In particular, it makes the point that women attracted by the dubious glamour of the military can also become casualties of the conflict. The play consists of six vignettes of violence. The first is far and away the best. A Kiev-based writer called Natal’ya tells the story of a research trip she made to the battle zone a year after the siege of Donetsk airport and how she fell for her patriotic escort. It is good precisely because it is personal, moving and filled with a double guilt: that of the confidence-revealing storyteller and of a woman who found love in a region where men were blowing each other to bits with rocket launchers. Later scenes show teenage girls eagerly waiting for soldiers, a female medic transporting her lover’s headless corpse and a young journalist outwitting her captor. Vorozhbit overdoes the point that the soldiers, for all their supposed heroism in the fight against separatists, either prove useless in the sack or reliant on oral satisfaction. I’d have liked to hear more about the complex politics behind the pitched battles.
-------

He plans to launch a homemade rocket in California as part of a bid to eventually prove that the Earth is flat. Hughes has spent $20,000 (£15,000) building the steam-powered rocket in his spare time, and will be livestreaming the launch over the internet. The self-described daredevil says he switched his focus to rockets after twice breaking his back doing stunt jumps in cars. “I don’t believe in science,” declared the 61-year-old. “I know about aerodynamics and fluid dynamics and how things move through the air. It is sponsored by a flat Earth research group, and Hughes plans a subsequent trip to try and observe the flatness of the Earth for himself. Speaking about the risks of the flight, Hughes said: “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.” Hughes’ website describes him as “the only man to design, build and launch himself in a rocket” – he previously flew in his own rocket in 2014, as this footage shows. Hughes has stated that once he lands at the weekend, he intends to announce that he is running for the governorship of California.

The inspectors say that many of the recommendations from their January inspection have not been met and the centre has deteriorated in most respects, including to do with safety, care, education, resettlement and the “effectiveness of leaders and managers”. They say that unacceptable behaviour, including swearing, intimidation and vandalism, is not being challenged by staff. Oakhill’s newly appointed interim director, Lisette Saunders, said: “We take these findings very seriously. In the report Ofsted recognised that senior managers at Oakhill know what is required to bring the centre up to acceptable standards.

On a date unlike any other, a young care worker named Lily found herself dining alone at a bustling café in the middle of the city. The date was a sign that she hadn’t lost hope in the magic of human connection. Her nose was tingling with the rich aromas of freshly baked pastries and steaming coffees, but she wasn't there to eat. Her stomach was busy with thoughts of her patients, the ones who looked into her eyes and saw a future they no longer believed could exist. She brought a small notebook to jot down the conversations she overheard, for the writing would later remind her of the human spirit that maintained its strength even in the simplest of moments.

As she observed the patrons, Lily noticed a couple seated at a corner table. They were deeply engrossed in their own conversation, oblivious to the world around them. It was in their interaction that she found a poignant reminder of the significance of connection, it being the very thing she sought to bring back into her patients' lives through her work. For Lily, the best thing about dining on her own wasn’t the freedom to order what she wanted, but the opportunity to witness the many faces and stories displayed on the varied stages of her surroundings.

Her writing was a private extension of her experience as a care worker. Each page was a testament to the power of genuine connections, the joy found in even the most basic of human exchanges, and the necessity to uplift the human spirit when the surroundings would otherwise rob it of its light. With every entry, Lily nurtured her own soul, reflecting on her role as a caregiver and a symbol of hope, amidst a world that was slowly lighting up the nights, but not in a good way. Her love for people-watching and her reflections on the human condition were, in essence, the vital threads that stitched together her identities as both a worker and a thinker.

 The world is changing as new technologies rip through old economies. The prospect of life outside the European Union will alter how we trade, move goods and people around and make our way in the world. For a long time these questions about the future have been neglected by national governments – left to the market, to globalisation, to Brussels. Now we need active change. To provide it, the government is launching its industrial strategy white paper, which will be published next Monday and heavily trailed during this week’s budget. In a welcome move, Theresa May has already outlined how the government plans to increase public and private R&D investment by up to £80bn over the next 10 years. The prime minister also announced £1.7bn to improve transport links within city regions. This comes as the UK is in serious need of new thinking to address fundamental long-term economic challenges: poor productivity, unbalanced regional growth and a weak track record in translating knowledge creation into inclusive wealth creation. The impact of the financial collapse in 2008 and the recent decision to leave the EU have only exacerbated these deep-seated national problems. A long-term industrial strategy for the UK that includes proper investment in R&D and connectivity is overdue.

 This compilation of a score of up-and-coming Brit acts has plenty to commend it, but its adopted “alt-folk” tagline proves fanciful. Most tracks are by gentle singer-songwriters of conventional hue, while the wilder reaches of wyrd folk - encounters with shape-shifters on stormy moors – are almost entirely absent. There are some forceful characters on display nonetheless. Brooke Sharkey offers airy, Anglo-French chamber folk. Ferris and Sylvester combine dreamy pop with spiky sentiments on Save Yourself (alt Simon and Garfunkel perhaps) and seven-piece Mishaped Pearls bring a cinematic sweep to Six Dukes. A rewarding sampler of a vibrant live scene, and not-for-profit with it.
-------

response:
The world of British alternative folk is bustling with young talents, although the tag "alt-folk" seems to stretch the imagination more than it captures the actual content of a new compilation album. This musical journey features a dozen or more up-and-coming artists who, despite the adventurous name of the genre, mostly adhere to a milder, tradition-oriented style. Wanderers in the more experimental realms of folk—those who might sing of supernatural happenings amidst raging storms and misty moors—are, unfortunately, in short supply.

Yet, the album has its luminaries. Brooke Sharkey, for instance, enchants with an ethereal blend of Anglo-French chamber folk, her voice light as a feather in the wind. Ferris and Sylvester add their touch to the mix, their song "Save Yourself" weaving a tapestry of dreamy pop melodies with a hint of angularity that suggests a crossing of paths with a classic duo like Simon and Garfunkel. Mishaped Pearls, a large ensemble of seven musicians, rounds up this musical party with their dramatic flair in "Six Dukes", a track that manages to evoke the grandiosity of a film score.

This compilation, deliberately crafted as a not-for-profit venture, stands as a vibrant testimony to the richness of the live music scene, brimming with creative force that promises to continue stirring the cultural pot.

P.P.S. It's evident that this new compilation offers a refreshing dip into the broad canvas of British folk, even if the stretch to "alt-folk" is significant. Let's hope that, in the future, more adventurous sounds will find their voice here.

 An appeal against a ban on Silvio Berlusconi holding public office is to be heard by the European court of human rights, in a move that could potentially see Italy’s scandal-tainted former prime minister leading the country again. The hearing on Wednesday, six years after he was forced from office, follows his success at forging a winning coalition out of his centre-right Forza Italia and two far-right parties – the Northern League and Brothers of Italy – in regional elections in Sicily earlier this month. The outcome of the ballot on the southern Italian island was largely seen as a rehearsal for how things might play out in national elections, which must be held before May next year. It also marked the beginning of an authentic political comeback for the 81-year-old, despite being plagued by a tax fraud conviction, sex scandals and allegations of corruption. Considering the length of time it takes for the court to deliver a verdict, it is unlikely to come before the general elections. The current five-year term for the Italian government officially expires on 15 March, although the vote could be held as late as May. “I hope that the Strasbourg court will accept my appeal,” Berlusconi wrote on Twitter on Wednesday. “But my role in the next electoral campaign is clear regardless: I will be in the field looking to take the centre-right into government.” The billionaire, who was forced to resign from his third term as prime minister in 2011 over claims he paid for sex with an underage sex worker, has hired top lawyers from London’s Doughty Street Chambers to fight his case. He was ejected from parliament and banned from running for office for six years in 2013 due to his tax fraud conviction. “We’ll have just 30 minutes to set out our argument, the same goes for the government,” Andrea Saccucci, one of the lawyers who will represent Berlusconi in the Strasbourg court, told the Guardian.

 ‘My motto is: try everything, life is short,” says John Dwyer, the leader of San Francisco garage rockers Thee Oh Sees. “We are growing at every turn. Every day you get a little older, a little closer to the grave – you should taste it all.” A master of contemporary garage rock, he came into prominence as part of the fruitful San Francisco scene of the early 2000s. Since then Thee Oh Sees have rattled out 21 LPs of bewilderingly consistent quality, under various iterations of their name, and Dwyer has written, recorded and released another 20 albums with other collaborators, encompassing everything from industrial electronics to improvised jazz and death metal. In a recent interview with Marc Maron, Dwyer talked of his love of Scott Walker and, in particular, a scene in the Walker documentary 30th Century Man when a percussionist is recorded punching a side of beef; Dwyer has similarly tried to master new sounds, be it a flute on Thee Oh Sees’ Dog Poison or electronic bagpipes on his most recent Damaged Bug LP. His career is full of examples of how to explore genres on a shoestring, too – there are projects that are just drums and vocals (the Drums) or a hefty death metal record squeezed out of three people (Dig That Body Up, It’s Alive).  The UK, even today, is not well blessed with festivals devoted to new music. But when the Huddersfield contemporary music festival began, in 1978, the situation was much worse, with no annual showcase here for what living composers were producing. That such an event took root in an unprepossessing West Yorkshire industrial town in the late 70s was remarkable in itself, especially when most of the activity in new music then was centred on London. What began on a modest scale under the aegis of Huddersfield Polytechnic (now the University of Huddersfield) – where the festival’s tireless founding director, Richard Steinitz, was a lecturer in music – grew quickly into one of the most important dates in the British musical calendar. The HCMF really hit its stride in the early 80s, hosting a series of important premieres alongside residencies from many of the senior figures of postwar music, from Olivier Messiaen and Terry Riley to Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter. Gradually expanding its ambition and range, Steinitz’s programming was never narrowly doctrinal; from the early days, he tried to reflect the spectrum of what was going on across Europe and the US. Steinitz stood down as director after the 2000 festival. The current director, Graham McKenzie, has been there for more than a decade, not only steering the programming towards new generations of composers from across Europe, but also broadening the stylistic scope, including events that touch on jazz, electronica and rock. With these changes, so the atmosphere of the festival has altered. This is partly because the generation of postwar composers whose appearances made the early festivals so memorable has all but gone, but also because, in those days, festival audiences had a sense of a shared purpose.

 Concordia International, the Canadian drug company, has overcharged the NHS by more than £100m in the past decade for a life-changing thyroid drug, according to Britain’s competition watchdog. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had provisionally found that Concordia had “abused its dominant position to overcharge the NHS” by hiking the price of liothyronine, used to treat patients with an underactive thyroid, by nearly 6,000% between 2007 and 2017. The regulator said the NHS had spent more than £34m on the drug last year, up from about £600,000 in 2006. The amount it paid per pack rose from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by July 2017. The price of a single pill went up from 16p to £9.22, even though production costs remained broadly stable during that period, the CMA said. Concordia could be fined up to 10% of its worldwide annual turnover. Liothyronine tablets are used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition caused by a deficiency of the thyroid hormone that affects at least two in 100 people and can lead to depression, tiredness and weight gain. For many patients there is no alternative and, until this year, Concordia was the only supplier. This summer, the UK firm Morningside Healthcare and Israel’s Teva were granted licences to supply the drug. The medicine, a synthetic version of the hormone T3, is taken by patients who do not respond well to the cheaper alternative, levothyroxine.

The American player and commentator Pam Shriver, who was a good friend, explained this by saying that Novotná was “as kind as she was athletic”. Others, mostly tennis writers such as myself, put it more brutally: she was a choker. Novotná herself said she hated the idea of choking, preferring instead to say that she “got a little tight”. Her most famous episode of getting a little tight is now a case study for sports psychologists. It came in the 1993 Wimbledon final when she led Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and at 40-30 in the sixth game of the deciding set had a service point for a 5-1 lead over the German.

 EasyJet saw its profits fall 17% last year, with more than £100m lost due to the slump in the pound after the Brexit vote. The airline reported a record year for passenger numbers, flying 80.2 million people, almost 10% more than in 2015-16, on ever fuller planes. But while revenues exceeded £5bn in 2016-17, fares dipped to fill seats in what the chief executive, Carolyn McCall, said was “a difficult year for the aviation industry”. McCall said: “Our planned approach of achieving number one or two positions at Europe’s leading airports, friendly and efficient customer service and a continuous focus on sustainable cost control, has put easyJet at a strategic advantage during a period when there have been bankruptcies and some airlines have struggled operationally.” Profits before tax fell from £494m to £408m. Despite paying a lower dollar price for fuel, the continued weakness of sterling brought additional costs of £101m, easyJet said. The airline will also be prompted by Brexit to change its rules to ensure easyJet is majority owned and controlled by EU nationals after 2019. About a third of shares are owned by the easyJet founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who has dual UK-Cypriot nationality, and will be classed as EU-owned. But easyJet will ask at its 2018 AGM for new powers to force UK shareholders to sell up if necessary to allow it to continue operating in Europe. McCall said the move was “a technical, administrative thing” and the airline had “no concerns” about getting enough EU shareholders. Shares rose by more than 5% in early trading, on the back of the airline reporting high levels of forward bookings and better revenue so far in its 2017-18 financial year, which it said was “primarily as a result of some capacity leaving the market”.

I have eubacterium, built by bananas and barley which, since I hate bananas, I can only ascribe to my high consumption of Ovaltine.

response:
The story of my microbiome journey might as well be a tale filled with the songs of Native American tribes, where the value of harmony with nature isn’t just spoken in cultural contexts but reminded through every banana, every bite of natural food, and every dietary decision that shapes one's gut health. Mention any environmental activist biologist, and their ears would perk up at the mention of the gut microbiome, a field that similarly sings the hymns of biodiversity, except this time, the ecosystems are within us.

Right in the heart of my narrative, the choice hangs heavy: stick with the cardboard-tasting concoctions touted by the Urban Citizen regime or raise a toast, or rather a smoothie, to the gods of the gut, the Indigenes and Village Peasants. My attempt at the latter began with a test, a £125 excursion into my inner realms, analyzing the microbial traffic in my gut. This cost feels justified underlining the value of knowing what you are ingesting, and how vital it is to our overall well-being.

Reluctantly, I find myself sitting on the side of the Village Peasants, dispensing the dirt on health from the comfort of my toilet bowl. This classification signals a diet bustling with fibres, probiotics that spell life away from fretting visits to the clinic. An array of bacteria, like Dorea, peeks its eye into view, promising a lesser flush of the loo with decreased chances of inflammatory bowel diseases, and eubacterium cheekily planted by an insubstantial consumption of bananas and a significant quantity of the delectable Ovaltine. My hygiene mantras whispered, “bananas are for the birds; Ovaltine, now that’s a choice lined more with comfort and tradition.”

Music to my microbiomes' ears, this diet sings of vitality and reminds me of a life somewhere amidst the smoke of grassland bonfires, where the Village Peasants' ethos of food syncs better with the gut’s orchestra than the Urban Citizen's shadow.

However, the journey prompts me to question, in a world that seems to favor stick-to-a-diet approaches, whether we truly understand or appreciate the dynamic, ever-fluctuating nature of microbiomes. This introspection ensures,Regardless of how the labels fluctuate, the narrative I penned down sparks a new chapter in my health diary, valuing the sync I’ve got with my inner terrain.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The campaign group that encouraged Paperchase to apologise for its marketing activities with the Daily Mail is pushing for John Lewis, the department store chain, to stop advertising with the newspaper as well as with the Sun and Daily Express. John Lewis has become a prime target for Stop Funding Hate on the back of the launch of its Christmas advert and as retailers increase their spending on advertising as the festive season approaches. Stop Funding Hate has produced a mock advert that depicts the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert – Buster the dog – as unhappy because the retailer is buying adverts with the Mail, Sun, and Express. The video has been shared almost 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate. The organisation was founded last year and says its aim is to take on “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun and Express, and persuade advertisers to cease their financial input. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, said: “[John Lewis] are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for. Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, John Lewis said it would continue advertising with the newspapers and not bow to the pressure. A spokesperson said: “Withdrawing advertising on the basis of editorial coverage would be inconsistent with our democratic principles, which include freedom of speech and remaining apolitical.” Paperchase announced on Monday that it would not run any marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail and said it was “truly sorry” for running a front-page promotion in Saturday’s edition of the newspaper.
-------

Classic retail campaigns during the holiday season often bring together consumers and brands in a celebration of shared values. This year, however, the spotlight has shifted to the ethical considerations behind advertisers choosing publications to promote their products. The John Lewis Christmas advert, a tradition deeply cherished by many, has inadvertently thrust the company into the center of a debate over corporate ethics and media responsibility. With a petition from the campaign group Stop Funding Hate, the department store chain is under pressure to reconsider its advertising strategy, particularly its associations with newspapers like the Daily Mail, Sun, and Daily Express.

Stop Funding Hate’s approach is aggressive and direct, employing a viral marketing strategy to create awareness and moral pressure on John Lewis and other major retailers. This is exemplified by their production of a mock advertisement involving last year’s beloved John Lewis dog mascot, Buster, to highlight the contradictions in John Lewis’s advertising choices versus its ethical branding. The campaign has garnered significant traction on social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter, with the video message against ‘hate-funding’ circulating widely amongst the public. This social media push is aimed to build a coalition of consumers who believe that companies like John Lewis should not support media known for divisive content.

Despite the public pressure from Stop Funding Hate and widespread online support, however, John Lewis has been firm in its commitment to advertising with contentious publications. The company’s stance is defended on the grounds of upholding democratic principles, including freedom of speech and a policy of remaining politically neutral. During the holiday season, this situation places John Lewis in a precarious position, as retailers prepare to ramp up advertising efforts. The holiday campaigns are traditionally used to enhance brand loyalty; however, the current风波也为品牌忠诚度带来了挑战，尤其是在涉及具有强烈价值观和服务理念的企业时，如John Lewis所代表的那样。随着圣诞节的临近，该品牌该如何平衡其伦理承诺与确保品牌信息广泛覆盖的需求，成为了一个棘手的问题。在这样的背景下，不仅仅是John Lewis，整个零售行业都可能需要重新审视它们在支持媒体选择上所承诺的道德价值观，以及这些选择对他们品牌形象的长期影响。
